comments.body:
There is a chance that the deletion (as a result of `kubectl delete` above) will succeed _before_ we run this `kubectl wait` command, i.e. this test could succeed even if the `wait` command is not implemented correctly.

To make this test case more reliable, we could start `kubectl wait --for=delete` _first_, and only then execute `kubectl delete` in a separate thread.
Not sure how hard it would be to implement with a shell script though, but we can write a similar unit test in Go (in addition to this change).
It isn't super important, the unit tests on this command are quite thorough compared to others
Also I chose a namespace because they tend to delete very slowly because of finalizers

comments.body:
@deads2k I omitted a test for `$ kubectl get kind/myobj` as it currently fails with:
```
$ kubectl get kind/myobj -o name
the server doesn't have a resource type "kind"
```

When only a kind is given, we hit [this condition](https://github.com/kubernetes/kubernetes/pull/59353/files#diff-80a5c1e5d1429094c6ecb3ae22847912R615) in the resource builder, where we ask the mapper for a restmapping, using a GroupKind with no group, and an empty version.

We end up going through the [priority restmapper's RESTMapping method](https://github.com/kubernetes/apimachinery/blob/master/pkg/api/meta/priority.go#L156), which in turn calls the [default restmapper's RESTMappings method](https://github.com/kubernetes/apimachinery/blob/master/pkg/api/meta/restmapper.go#L485). 

That method attempts to iterate through any versions given (none in this case), and then attempts to use the default groupversions which were [passed to the instance here](https://github.com/kubernetes/kubernetes/blob/master/staging/src/k8s.io/client-go/discovery/restmapper.go#L92) in order to find any group versions with a matching group name.

Since we have an empty group in this case (only using kind), this method then [proceeds to fail](https://github.com/kubernetes/apimachinery/blob/master/pkg/api/meta/restmapper.go#L513), causing us to ultimately end up with the error from the example above.

[I have a patch here](https://gist.github.com/juanvallejo/1c77c14d18b14f15c09377cff0a02369) that iterates through stored gvks on the restmapper instance (added through the [AddSpecific method here](https://github.com/kubernetes/kubernetes/blob/master/staging/src/k8s.io/client-go/discovery/restmapper.go#L110)) and does the same thing that we already attempt to do with groups: iterates through stored gvks, looking for ones that have matching `kind`s.

I have tested this patch locally with [Jordan's example](https://github.com/kubernetes/kubernetes/pull/59227#issuecomment-363173986), and works as expected when attempting to fetch resources by only specifying their kind. PTAL

Isn't failure there exactly what we expect on the kind match (which shouldn't match because that isn't the kind group) and the code should fail through to the resource matching?  Why isn't it doing that?

> @deads2k I omitted a test for $ kubectl get kind/myobj as it currently fails with:

That means this pull is broken.  You should be up front about the pull be broken by putting the broken test in your pull.

> Isn't failure there exactly what we expect on the kind match (which shouldn't match because that isn't the kind group) and the code should fail through to the resource matching? Why isn't it doing that?

It is doing that. The code for resource matching is what ultimately ends up returning the error message `the server doesn't have a resource type "kind"`. I have added a test for `kubectl get kind -o name`

> @deads2k I omitted a test for $ kubectl get kind/myobj as it currently fails with:
> 
> $ kubectl get kind/myobj -o name
> the server doesn't have a resource type "kind"

kind is always paired with group for all non-legacy kinds.  Legacy kinds all match their resources.  We don't have to worry about this case.

comments.body: Why not `CustomResourceDefinition`? (not compulsory, just curious what's the formal name we are using)
+1. It's better to use the full name.

This does a `kubectl get foos` which lists the _instances_ of our custom type i.e. it lists the "custom resources". [This](https://github.com/nikhita/kubernetes/blob/694630724a1e5036d35ed9c12dc97dd2989d15d6/hack/testdata/CRD/foo.yaml) is an instance of type `Foo` .

For the `CustomResourceDefinition` (where we register the type `Foo`), we need to do `kubectl get crd`, which is done [here](https://github.com/nikhita/kubernetes/blob/694630724a1e5036d35ed9c12dc97dd2989d15d6/hack/make-rules/test-cmd-util.sh#L1480).
So it seems to be mixed usage or inconsistency?
CRDs and CRs are two different things.

comments.body: I'm not feeling good about this change. Why not checking `$?`?
What are you worried about @mengqiy ?
`record_command` will check every command's `$?`, so for command with no arguments provided, we need to inverse the value of `$?` so that `record_command` can be pass,
maybe not every command, but it will check the last value of $? in each functions, iirc, so we need to make sure every function's `$?` is zero

> What are you worried about @mengqiy ?

Maybe this is fine.
I'm not sure what is the best practice here to check the exit code and output at the same time.

comments.body:
From help text:
```
--request-timeout='0': The length of time to wait before giving up on a single server request. Non-zero values should contain a corresponding time unit (e.g. 1s, 2m, 3h). A value of zero means don't timeout requests.
```

I don't understand why you give `--request-timeout=1`. And it's not clear to me that timeout is 1s or 1m or ...

I think it's b/c I left a comment about it. If we don't specify a timeout, the test spend 30s here for the blocked initializer. Now I'm suspecting this 1s might cause flakes, I'm not sure making it another value like `5s` would help prevent the flake at all.

> I don't understand why you give --request-timeout=1

@mengqiy I've added pending initializers in the yaml, which will keep blocking until timeout. Per [discussion](https://github.com/kubernetes/kubernetes/pull/50497#discussion_r134922857).

> And it's not clear to me that timeout is 1s or 1m or ...

Just follow other commands in the [test files](https://github.com/dixudx/kubernetes/blob/d80ff0f60c7d903305c740a6271616297f1570f7/hack/make-rules/test-cmd-util.sh#L1408). Actually `--request-timeout=1` means 1sec.

Since the flag description of `--request-timeout` is quite confusing. We may consider to elaborate it.
Make sense.

comments.body: is it necessary to do this in every one of these functions?
we need to not fail the test if the sh2ju.sh script exits non-0 because that is expected for failed tests.  do you know of a better way of doing this?

the usual way to handle something returning nonzero with `errexit` is to do something like
```bash
mycmd && rc=$? || rc=$?
if [[ "${rc}" != 0 ]]; then
...
```

It will look like 
```
    juLog -output="${output}" -class="test-cmd" -name="${name}" "$@" && rc=$? || rc=$?
    if [[ "${rc}" != 0 ]]; then
      echo "Error when running ${name}"
      foundError="True"
    fi
```
The first line will become really long. But I will update it as you suggested.

yeah, that's pretty much the way shell works. you can always break into several lines with \.

if it can avoid us having the `set -o` / `set +o` stuff everywhere it's an improvement, though.
(you're also welcome to do this in a followup PR or something. having junit for test-cmd is a huge improvement, and I don't mean to block that progress.)
I will address the remaining comments in a followup PR. I want to get this PR merged ASAP. Otherwise, I can imagine I will fall into endless rebase when the queue open again.

I have a unit test in validation. Is that not enough?
I'm just wondering if this test adds anything over the unit test you've already put in.

I see. The validation unit test only tests the validation part. I still want to test that after updating a DaemonSet with a semantically equal change, templateGeneration won't change. It can't be done in DaemonSet controller unit test, because templateGeneration is updated by API server but not DaemonSet controller.
was this for style or did this stop working?

Not sure how to make nested index work.
`{{.some-field}}` seems not allowed, because of `-`.
For 1 layer indexing, we can use `{{index . \"some-field\"}}`. I don't know how to make it work for 2 layer indexing. So using this style `{{.someField.someSubfield}}` to make my life easier.

just pass multiple tokens to index and it traverses:
```
kubectl get bar/test -o jsonpath='{.some-field.some-sub-field}'
kubectl get bar/test -o go-template='{{index . "some-field" "some-sub-field"}}'
```

diffHunk:
@@ -1,1 +1285,1289 @@  kubectl "${kube_flags[@]}" get foos/test -o "jsonpath={.someField}"          --allow-missing-template-keys=false
  kubectl "${kube_flags[@]}" get foos      -o "go-template={{range .items}}{{.someField}}{{end}}" --allow-missing-template-keys=false
  kubectl "${kube_flags[@]}" get foos/test -o "go-template={{.someField}}"                        --allow-missing-template-keys=false

comments.body:
SUPPORTED_RESOURCES is not a comma separated list, it is a bash array.

We'll never hit this echo if it was unset, since we'd die on the set -e. I think it should be be `if [[ -z "${SUPPORTED_RESOURCES:-}" ]]` for the (wrong) comment to ever pop...

diffHunk:
@@ -1,1 +2418,2422 @@  if [ -z "${SUPPORTED_RESOURCES:-}" ]; then
    echo "Need to set SUPPORTED_RESOURCES env var. It is a list of resources that are supported and hence should be tested. Set it to (*) to test all resources"
    exit 1
  fi
  kube::log::status "Checking kubectl version"

comments.body: This should be outside of `runTests`? Otherwise all calls to `create_and_use_new_namespace` won't work

This is for use by functions called by runTests so it works fine without moving it out.
I dont want to move it out since that will mean making `$i` global. create_and_use_new_namespace uses `$i` to keep track of how many namespaces has it created and appends it to ns name to create unique ns names.
